questions.text: Which of the following marked structures represents Danger space ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows the Transverse section of the neck and the Danger area is marked as D in the image. The danger area is the retropharyngeal space that extends from the base of the skull to the diaphragm.

  • The danger area is a potential space located between the alar fascia (anteriorly) and prevertebral fascia (posteriorly).
  • It extends:
    • Superiorly: from the base of the skull
    • Inferiorly: down to the diaphragm (T12 level)
  • It is clinically important because:
    • Infections from the retropharyngeal space can enter the danger space and descend rapidly into the mediastinum, leading to mediastinitis, a life-threatening condition.
  • Key fascial layers to know:
    • Buccopharyngeal fascia (anterior)
    • Alar fascia (middle)
    • Prevertebral fascia (posterior)

questions.text: Identify marked strap muscle enveloped by deep cervical fascia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked strap muscle shown in the image is the omohyoid, which is enveloped by the investing layer of the deep cervical fascia.

  • The omohyoid muscle is one of the infrahyoid (strap) muscles and has two bellies:
    • Superior belly: inserts into the hyoid bone
    • Inferior belly: originates from the superior border of the scapula
  • These bellies are connected by an intermediate tendon, which is anchored to the clavicle by a fascial sling derived from the investing layer of deep cervical fascia.
  • Function: Depresses the hyoid bone and larynx during swallowing and speech.
  • Innervation: Anterior rami of C1 to C3 through the ansa cervicalis.

Explanation of other options:

Sternohyoid (Option B): Lies medial to omohyoid, arises from the manubrium and inserts into the hyoid, not showing the distinct lateral path with intermediate tendon seen in omohyoid.

Sternothyroid (Option C): Lies deep to sternohyoid, runs from manubrium to thyroid cartilage, and is not visible laterally as the marked structure.

Thyrohyoid (Option D): Connects thyroid cartilage to hyoid bone, lies superior to sternothyroid, and is more medial and deep, not the lateral muscle shown.

questions.text: What is the anterior relation to scalene muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The vagus nerve lies anterior to the scalene muscles, particularly the anterior scalene, making it an important anterior relation.

  • The scalene muscles (anterior, middle, posterior) arise from the cervical vertebrae and insert onto the first and second ribs.
  • The anterior scalene muscle is a key landmark in the neck because of the important structures passing in front of, behind, and between it.
  • Anterior relations to anterior scalene:
    • Phrenic nerve (crosses obliquely on its anterior surface)
    • Vagus nerve (descends within the carotid sheath anterior and medial to scalene)
    • Subclavian vein
    • Transverse cervical and suprascapular vessels
  • Between anterior and middle scalene:
    • Subclavian artery
    • Brachial plexus (roots and trunks)
  • Posterior relations:
    • Cervical pleura
    • Vertebral artery (ascends posteriorly into the transverse foramina)

Explanation of other options:

Cervical Pleura (Option A): Lies posterior and medial to the scalene muscles, forming part of the apex of the lung (cupula).

Subclavian artery (Option B): Passes between the anterior and middle scalene, not anterior to them.

Vertebral artery (Option C): Arises from the subclavian artery and passes posterior to the scalene muscles, entering the transverse foramen of C6.

questions.text: A patient with long standing atherosclerosis and 70% coronary artery blockage is now presenting with a stroke. Diagnosis of Carotid artery narrowing is made. Which branch of the internal carotid artery will not be involved in this case ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ophthalmic artery arises after the internal carotid artery enters the cranial cavity via the carotid canal and cavernous sinus. Thus, it is spared in extracranial carotid artery narrowing.

  • The internal carotid artery (ICA) is divided into cervical, petrous, cavernous, and cerebral parts.
  • In atherosclerotic carotid artery disease, the narrowing typically occurs extracranially, especially at the bifurcation of the common carotid artery into internal and external carotids (usually around C3-C4 vertebral levels).
  • The ophthalmic artery is the first intracranial branch of the ICA and arises after it has traversed the cavernous sinus and entered the cranial cavity.
  • Therefore, it is spared in extracranial narrowing.

Explanation of other options:

Inferior hypophyseal artery (Option A): Arises from the cavernous part of ICA; can be affected by intracranial ICA stenosis or proximal narrowing extending into the cranial cavity.

Meningeal artery (Option C): Small meningeal twigs can arise from the cavernous segment of the ICA and may be involved in ICA pathology.

Branches to the trigeminal ganglion (Option D): These also arise from the cavernous part of the ICA and may be involved in intracranial ICA pathology.

questions.text: Which of these branches of the trigeminal nerve contain somatic motor processes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the listed nerves are purely sensory branches of the trigeminal nerve and do not carry somatic motor fibers.

  • The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) is the principal sensory nerve of the face and has three main divisions:
    • V1 - Ophthalmic (purely sensory)
    • V2 - Maxillary (purely sensory)
    • V3 - Mandibular (both sensory and motor)
  • Motor fibers of CN V are exclusively carried by V3 (mandibular division) and supply the:
    • Muscles of mastication (masseter, temporalis, medial & lateral pterygoid)
    • Mylohyoid and anterior belly of digastric
    • Tensor tympani and tensor veli palatini
  • However, even within V3, terminal branches like the mental nerve are sensory only.

Explanation of other options:

The supraorbital nerve (Option A): A branch of V1 (ophthalmic); purely sensory to forehead and scalp.

The infraorbital nerve (Option B): A branch of V2 (maxillary); sensory to lower eyelid, upper lip, and cheek.

The mental nerve (Option C): A terminal sensory branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (from V3); carries only sensory fibers to the chin and lower lip, not motor.

choices.text: Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of the following are NOT a branch of the external carotid artery in Kiesselbach's plexus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of ophthalmic artery (from the internal carotid system), not the external carotid artery.

  • Kiesselbach's plexus (Little's area) is a vascular network located on the anterior part of the nasal septum, and it is a common site of epistaxis (nosebleed).
  • It receives contributions from both the internal and external carotid artery systems.
  • External carotid artery contributions:
    • Sphenopalatine artery (terminal branch of maxillary artery)
    • Greater palatine artery (branch of descending palatine from maxillary artery)
    • Superior labial artery (branch of facial artery) → septal branch contributes to plexus
  • Internal carotid artery contribution:
    • Anterior ethmoidal artery (branch of ophthalmic artery)
  • Clinical Importance:
    • Easily accessible and manageable with conservative treatment (e.g., pinching, nasal packing)
    • Children and young adults are more commonly affected
    • Trauma, dryness, and inflammation make it vulnerable

Woodruff's Plexus

  • Location:
    • Posterior part of the inferior nasal meatus, near the lateral nasal wall
    • Situated deep within the posterior nasal cavity
  • Venous Plexus:
    • Unlike Kiesselbach's, Woodruff's plexus is primarily venous
    • Composed of thin-walled venous channels, which drain into the pterygoid venous plexus
  • Clinical Importance:
    • Common source of posterior epistaxis
    • More serious than anterior bleeds-difficult to visualize and control
    • Often associated with older adults and hypertensive patients
    • May require posterior nasal packing or surgical ligation

Explanation of other options:

Sphenopalatine artery (Option A): Terminal branch of the maxillary artery (external carotid); contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus.

Greater palatine artery (Option C): Branch of maxillary artery (external carotid); runs through greater palatine canal to nasal septum.

Septal branch of superior labial artery (Option D): Branch of the facial artery (external carotid); supplies anterior nasal septum and part of the plexus.

choices.text: Frontal sinus, Superior concha, Inferior concha, Sphenoid sinus, Epiglottis, Hyoid bone, Thyroid cartilage, Cricoid cartilage
Sphenoid sinus, Inferior concha, Superior concha, Frontal sinus, Thyroid cartilage, Cricoid cartilage, Hyoid bone, Epiglottis
Superior concha, Frontal sinus, Sphenoid sinus, Inferior concha, Hyoid bone, Epiglottis, Thyroid cartilage, Cricoid cartilage
Frontal sinus, Inferior concha, Superior concha, Sphenoid sinus, Cricoid cartilage, Thyroid cartilage, Hyoid bone, Epiglottis

questions.text: Identify structures B, D, F, G, M, N, O, P
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structures marked with B, D, F, G, M, N, O, P are Frontal sinus, Superior concha, Inferior concha, Sphenoid sinus, Epiglottis, Hyoid bone, Thyroid cartilage, Cricoid cartilage respectively.

questions.text: Identify the structural landmark to secure Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN)
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Ligament of Berry is the most reliable anatomical landmark for locating and protecting the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) during thyroid surgery. It is marked as A in the image.

  • The Ligament of Berry is a thickened condensation of pretracheal fascia that tethers the posteromedial aspect of the thyroid gland to the trachea and cricoid cartilage.
  • The RLN passes deep or immediately adjacent to this ligament as it enters the larynx near the cricothyroid joint.
  • This close relationship makes it the key landmark for identifying the RLN intraoperatively, especially in thyroidectomies.
  • Clinical Relevance:
    • Injury to the RLN at the Ligament of Berry is a common complication during thyroid surgery, potentially resulting in hoarseness or airway issues.
    • Therefore, meticulous dissection around this ligament is crucial to preserve nerve function.

choices.text: Common carotid artery, Internal carotid artery, Internal jugular vein, CN 9
Common carotid artery, Internal carotid artery, Internal jugular vein, CN 10
Common carotid artery, Internal carotid artery, Internal jugular vein, CN 11
Common carotid artery, Internal carotid artery, Internal jugular vein, CN 1

questions.text: What is the content of the highlighted structure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The highlighted structure is Carotid sheath. The carotid sheath surrounds the following anatomical structures:

  • The common carotid artery (CC)
  • The internal carotid artery (I See = IC)
  • The internal jugular vein (IV).
  • The vagus nerve (CN X)

In order to remember this list of the main carotid sheath contents, a popular mnemonic is well worth learning: 'I See 10 CC's in the IV'

  • The carotid sheath is a tubular fascial structure in the deep neck fascia that encloses key neurovascular structures and extends from the base of the skull to the root of the neck.
  • Contents of the Carotid Sheath:
  • The internal carotid artery is found superiorly (after bifurcation of the common carotid artery), while the common carotid artery is in the inferior part of the sheath.

questions.text: Which of the following ganglions supply the gland given below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The gland shown in the image is a Parotid gland. The parotid gland receives parasympathetic innervation via the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) through the otic ganglion.

  • The otic ganglion is a parasympathetic ganglion located just below the foramen ovale, medial to the mandibular nerve in the infratemporal fossa.
  • Parasympathetic Pathway to Parotid Gland:
    • Inferior salivatory nucleus (in medulla) → gives preganglionic fibers via:
    • Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) → tympanic branch → forms tympanic plexus in middle ear.
    • From the plexus → lesser petrosal nerve → synapses in otic ganglion
    • Postganglionic fibers → travel with auriculotemporal nerve (V3) → parotid gland
  • This pathway stimulates salivary secretion from the parotid gland.

    • Explanation of other options:

    Geniculate ganglion (Option A): Contains sensory neurons of facial nerve, not involved in parotid innervation.

    Submandibular ganglion (Option C): Provides parasympathetic innervation to submandibular and sublingual glands, not the parotid.

    Inferior salivatory nucleus (Option D): Is the origin of preganglionic fibers, but not the ganglion that supplies the parotid gland directly.
